body_text.text: The differentiation propensities of human pluripotent stem cell (hPSC) lines vary from one line to another (Osafune et al., 2008;Bock et al., 2011;Chetty et al., 2013;Gage et al., 2013).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Some cell lines fail to yield terminally differentiated cells at subsequent stages of differentiation (Tabar and Studer, 2014).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: These limitations in the ability to systematically differentiate hPSC lines into desired lineages substantially restrict their utility for cell replacement therapy and disease modeling, as moving stem cell-based therapies to patients will require the ability to differentiate all cell lines.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Here, we show that PP1, a Src tyrosine kinase inhibitor, regulates the retinoblastoma protein (Rb) and cell cycle of hPSCs, enriches cells in the early G1 phase, and improves their multilineage differentiation potential.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Importantly, the PP1 treatment yields high differentiation efficiencies even in cell lines that have low differentiation propensities under control conditions.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: We demonstrate these effects in both human embryonic and induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC) lines.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Furthermore, we show that Src plays an important regulatory role in this process, as genetic suppression of Src regulates Rb activity and enhances the differentiation potential of hPSCs.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Our focus on PP1 and Src was motivated by the finding that the embryonic cell cycle lengthens to incorporate gap phases as it transitions from a proliferative stage to a stage governed by cell fate decisions (Trelstad et al., 1967;Hartwell and Weinert, 1989;Murray and Kirschner, 1989;Frederick and Andrews, 1994;Edgar and Lehner, 1996).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: One mechanism that plays a critical role in maintaining cell proliferation at the early developmental stages is Src tyrosine kinase signaling (Frame, 2002;Segawa et al., 2006;Kim et al., 2009).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: High protein tyrosine kinase activity is required for the early developmental events that occur before cell fate specification (Imamoto and Soriano, 1993;Livingston et al., 1998).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Analogous to early development, Src activity is elevated in proliferating PSCs (Annerén et al., 2004), potentially preventing the lengthening of the cell cycle for differentiation and cell fate specification.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: We therefore hypothesized that inhibiting Src activity might regulate the cell cycle and improve the differentiation propensity of hPSCs.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In previous work, we showed that treatment of hPSCs with DMSO improves differentiation propensity after directed differentiation (Chetty et al., 2013).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The present study provides a new tool to improve differentiation and strengthens the case that manipulating the cell cycle is critical for improving directed differentiation.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The mechanistic results presented here indicate that Src plays an important regulatory role in controlling cell fate decisions of hPSCs.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Src-tyrosine kinase signaling regulates cell growth and proliferation of various cell types, including PSCs (Annerén et al., 2004), cancer cells (Frame, 2002), and normal somatic cells Driving human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs) into specific lineages is an inefficient and challenging process.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: We show that a potent Src inhibitor, PP1, regulates expression of genes involved in the G1 to S phase transition of the cell cycle, activates proteins in the retinoblastoma family, and subsequently increases the differentiation propensities of hPSCs into all three germ layers.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: We further demonstrate that genetic suppression of Src regulates the activity of the retinoblastoma protein and enhances the differentiation potential of hPSCs across all germ layers.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: These positive effects extend beyond the initial germ layer specification and enable efficient differentiation at subsequent stages of differentiation.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: A Src inhibitor regulates the cell cycle of human pluripotent stem cells and improves directed differentiation (Playford and Schaller, 2004).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: In most cell types, Src is negatively regulated (held in an inactive state), but in PSCs and cancer cells, Src activity is elevated (Frame, 2002;Annerén et al., 2004).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: PP1 ( Fig. 1 A) has been shown to effectively block Src activity and the proliferation of many types of tumorigenic cells (Hanke et al., 1996;Bain et al., 2007).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: We tested whether inhibition of Src signaling by PP1 treatment affects the differentiation capacity of hPSCs.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: We focused on the hPSC line HUES6, a cell line with a 24-h doubling time that does not exhibit bias toward any particular lineage and is representative of cell lines with relatively low efficiencies of differentiation (Cowan et al., 2004;Osafune et al., 2008;Bock et al., 2011).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: To enhance therapeutic utility, differenti-ations were performed under low-serum conditions.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: After a 24-h treatment with PP1 at different doses, HUES6 cells were cultured in differentiation media with Wnt3a and Activin A for 24 h, then assessed for the percentage of cells that differentiated into Brachyury (Brachy)+ cells, a marker for mesendoderm and an early marker for differentiation ( Fig. 1 B).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: A 24-h treatment with PP1 increased the percentage as well as the total number of cells that differentiated compared with untreated control cells in a dose-dependent manner ( Fig. 1, C-F).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: At dosages of 25-50 µM, the percentage of cells differentiating into Brachy+ cells reached nearly 50%, an ∼300-fold enhancement relative to control cells.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: In all conditions, cells that did not differentiate retained the Figure 1.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner.

body_text.text: (A) Chemical structure of 4-amino-5-(4-methylphenyl)-7-(t-butyl)pyrazolo-d-3,4-pyrimidine (PP1).

body_text.text: (B) Schematic of directed differentiation of hPSCs into Brachy+ cells after no treatment (control) or a 24-h PP1 treatment at varying doses.

body_text.text: Percentages (C) and absolute numbers (D) of control and PP1-treated HUES6 hPSCs differentiating into Brachy+ cells in relation to the total cell numbers (E) in control and PP1-treated cultures.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: (F) Immunostaining for Oct4, Brachy, and DAPI in control and PP1-treated cultures after directed differentiation.

body_text.text: Error bars indicate SEM of three replicates.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: Bars,200 µM.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: pluripotency marker Oct4 (Fig. 1 F).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: Because a 25-µM PP1 treatment maximizes the percentage and total number of differentiated cells, we used this as an optimal dosage in subsequent analyses.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: Improvements in differentiation capacity were also observed in other human embryonic and iPSC lines after a 24-h PP1 (25 µM) treatment (Fig. 2).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: These improvements were driven by an enhanced competency for differentiation; across all cell lines, the rate of cell death did not differ sig-nificantly between the two groups ( Fig. S1; P = 0.3 Annexin+/ PI−; P = 0.1 Annexin+/PI+).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: The change in intercellular morphology with exposure to PP1 is consistent with the effects of Src activity on cell-cell adhesion (Frame, 2002;Playford and Schaller, 2004).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: While elevated Src activity disrupts cell-cell adhesion, inhibition of its activity is associated with improved multicellular interactions (Segawa et al., 2006).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: Cells treated with higher dosages of PP1 Figure 2.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: PP1 treatment improves differentiation capacity across hPSC lines.

body_text.text: (A) Schematic of directed differentiation of hPSCs into Brachy+ cells after no treatment (control) or a 24-h 25 µM PP1 treatment.

body_text.text: Percentages and absolute numbers of control and PP1-treated hPSCs differentiating into Brachy+ cells in the HUES8 (B and C), HUES49 (D and E), H9 (F and G), and iPSC 11b (H and I) hPSC lines.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: Error bars indicate SEM of two replicates (HUES49, H9, iPSC11b) or four replicates (HUES8).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner
PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: aggregate into tight, dense clusters distinct from the spread-out, planar arrangement of control cells and cells treated with low doses of PP1 ( Fig. 1 F).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: In addition to dosage, the duration of the PP1 treatment can also regulate the differentiation capacity of hPSCs.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: Treatment durations that were shorter than the cell line's doubling time induced only a 2-5% differentiation rate (unpublished data).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: Among the inhibitors tested, PP1 proved to be the most effective in enhancing differentiation potential.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: Consistent with prior reports, treatment of hPSCs with other inhibitors to perturb various cell cycle-related kinase signaling pathways had a minimal or moderate effect on improving differentiation potential (Smith, 2001;Orford and Scadden, 2008;Li and Kirschner, 2014).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: Treatment with a Cdk2 inhibitor at 5-10 µM induced ∼20% of the cells to differentiate into Brachy+ cells but was associated with a substantial degree of cell loss at higher doses (Fig. S2, A-I).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs in a dose-dependent manner

body_text.text: Given that the PP1 treatment effectively enhances differentiation potential at the 24 h time point, we treated hPSCs with 25 µM PP1 for 24 h and investigated the effects on the cell cycle.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment regulates the cell cycle and activity of Rb in hPSCs

body_text.text: Cell cycle analysis by flow cytometry showed that the PP1 treatment changes the distribution of hPSCs in the G1, S, and G2/M phases of the cell cycle, increasing the proportion of cells in G1 and decreasing the number of cells in the S and G2/M phases.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment regulates the cell cycle and activity of Rb in hPSCs

body_text.text: These effects were consistently observed in several human embryonic and iPSC lines (Figs. 3, 4 A, and S3).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment regulates the cell cycle and activity of Rb in hPSCs

body_text.text: Further investigation of the HUES6 cell line showed that a 24-h treatment with 25 µM PP1 nearly doubles the percentage of cells in G1 phase (∼70%) compared with controls (∼35%; Fig. 4 B).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment regulates the cell cycle and activity of Rb in hPSCs

body_text.text: The proportion of cells in the S and G2/M phases is concomitantly reduced by at least twofold after the PP1 treatment ( Fig. 4 B).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment regulates the cell cycle and activity of Rb in hPSCs

body_text.text: A significant shift toward G1 was observed across all cell lines ( Fig. 3 and Fig. S3; P < 0.002).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment regulates the cell cycle and activity of Rb in hPSCs

body_text.text: Rb predominantly remains in an inactive hyperphosphorylated state throughout the cell cycle of human and mouse PSCs.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment regulates the cell cycle and activity of Rb in hPSCs

body_text.text: While phosphorylated Rb promotes cell division, the accumulation of hypophosphorylated Rb (active Rb) is associated with an enrichment of cells in the early G1 phase of the cell cycle and an improved capacity for differentiation (Buchkovich et al., 1989;Chen et al., 1989;Orford and Scadden, 2008).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment regulates the cell cycle and activity of Rb in hPSCs

body_text.text: We assessed the phosphorylation status of Rb in control and 25 µM PP1-treated hPSCs.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment regulates the cell cycle and activity of Rb in hPSCs

body_text.text: After a 24-h PP1 treatment, the percentage of hPSCs expressing hypophosphorylated Rb increased by >60-fold from 0.3% to 20% (Fig. 4, C and D).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment regulates the cell cycle and activity of Rb in hPSCs

body_text.text: Phosphorylation of Rb occurs at 16 distinct sites (Harbour and Dean, 2000).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment regulates the cell cycle and activity of Rb in hPSCs

body_text.text: Assessment of the inactive phosphorylated status of Rb at one of these sites (serine 780) showed that PP1 treatment leads to a twofold reduction in the percentage of cells expressing pRb780 (Fig. 4, C and E).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment regulates the cell cycle and activity of Rb in hPSCs

body_text.text: The phosphorylation of Rb at serine 780 was also differentially regulated by other cell cycle inhibitors (Fig. S2 J).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment regulates the cell cycle and activity of Rb in hPSCs

body_text.text: In its hypophosphorylated state, Rb plays a critical role in growth suppression.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment regulates the cell cycle and activity of Rb in hPSCs

body_text.text: In coordination with Rb, the retinoblastoma-associated protein 46/48 (RbAP46/48; a histone chaperone protein) regulates the cell cycle by aiding in the transcriptional repression of Rb-related target genes, particularly genes involved in the G1 to S phase transition (Harbour and Dean, 2000;Taylor-Harding et al., 2004).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment regulates the cell cycle and activity of Rb in hPSCs

body_text.text: We assessed the fraction of cells expressing the cofactor RbAP46/48 in control and PP1-treated hPSCs.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment regulates the cell cycle and activity of Rb in hPSCs

body_text.text: Flow cytometry analysis showed that the percentage of hPSCs expressing RbAP46/48 nearly doubles between control and PP1-treated cells (Fig. 4, F and G).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment regulates the cell cycle and activity of Rb in hPSCs

body_text.text: Furthermore, treatment with 25 µM PP1 for 24 h also regulated the expression of many genes associated with cell cycle control.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment regulates the cell cycle and activity of Rb in hPSCs

body_text.text: The expression of genes promoting cell division, including Cyclin A1, Cdk2, and Cdc6, were significantly reduced in PP1-treated hPSCs relative to control cells ( Fig. 4 H).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment regulates the cell cycle and activity of Rb in hPSCs

body_text.text: Expression of p27, a cell cycle inhibitor that promotes growth arrest in G1 (Toyoshima and Hunter, 1994), was significantly increased in PP1-treated hPSCs compared with control cells (Fig. 4 H).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment regulates the cell cycle and activity of Rb in hPSCs

body_text.text: No significant difference in expression levels was observed for Cyclin A2, Cyclin D1, Cyclin E1, E2f1, and p21 between control and PP1-treated hPSCs (Fig. 4 H).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment regulates the cell cycle and activity of Rb in hPSCs

body_text.text: Together, these results show that PP1 treatment of hPSCs promotes growth inhibition and an accumulation of cells in the G1 phase by regulating genes involved in the G1 to S phase transition.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment regulates the cell cycle and activity of Rb in hPSCs

body_text.text: The enhanced hypophosphorylated state of Rb increases the proportion of cells in the early G1 phase and more generally indicates an increased presence of early G1 in the hPSC cycle after PP1 treatment.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment regulates the cell cycle and activity of Rb in hPSCs

body_text.text: Given that PP1 is a potent Src inhibitor (Hanke et al., 1996;Bain et al., 2007), we assessed whether treatment of hPSCs with PP1 reduced protein levels of Src.
body_text.section: Genetic suppression of Src regulates Rb activity and improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: Western blot analysis using two different Src specific antibodies showed that PP1 treatment does indeed suppress Src levels (Fig. 5 A).
body_text.section: Genetic suppression of Src regulates Rb activity and improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: To investigate whether suppression of Src mimics the effects of PP1 on hPSCs, we next genetically suppressed Src in hPSCs using siRNA.
body_text.section: Genetic suppression of Src regulates Rb activity and improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: siR-NA-mediated knockdown of Src suppressed both the gene expression ( Fig. 5 B) and protein ( Fig. 5 C) levels of Src in hPSCs.
body_text.section: Genetic suppression of Src regulates Rb activity and improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: Similar to PP1, Src knockdown also enhanced the activity of Rb by substantially reducing the levels of the phosphorylated and hyperphosphorylated forms of the Rb protein (ppRb) and increasing levels of the hypo-or underphosphorylated forms of Rb (Fig. 5 C).
body_text.section: Genetic suppression of Src regulates Rb activity and improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: Together with PP1, these results provide further support that inhibition of Src increases the proportion of hPSCs in the early G1 phase of the cell cycle.
body_text.section: Genetic suppression of Src regulates Rb activity and improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: Prior literature has shown that cells have an enhanced capacity to respond to extracellular signals in the G1 phase (Scott et al., 1982).
body_text.section: Genetic suppression of Src regulates Rb activity and improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: To investigate whether these effects regulate the differentiation propensity of hPSCs, we next assessed whether genetic suppression of Src improves the differentiation potential of hPSCs across all germ layers.
body_text.section: Genetic suppression of Src regulates Rb activity and improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: After Src knockdown of hPSCs with siRNA, we subsequently induced differentiation into each of the germ layers using three different directed differentiation protocols (Chetty et al., 2013;Fig. 5 D).
body_text.section: Genetic suppression of Src regulates Rb activity and improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: The percentage of cells becoming Sox1+, Brachy+, and Sox17+ cells was quantified to assess multilineage differentiation potential into the ectodermal, mesodermal, and endodermal germ layers, respectively (Fig. 5 D).
body_text.section: Genetic suppression of Src regulates Rb activity and improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: Transfection of hPSCs with Src siRNA before directed differentiation significantly increased the number and percentage of differentiated cells across all three germ layers (Fig. 5, E and F).
body_text.section: Genetic suppression of Src regulates Rb activity and improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: After Src knockdown, the percentage of hPSCs that differentiated into each germ layer was enhanced by ∼2-10-fold ( Fig. 5 F).
body_text.section: Genetic suppression of Src regulates Rb activity and improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: At the time points assessed, differentiation rates of ∼50% were observed across all the germ layers after Src knockdown (Fig. 5 F).
body_text.section: Genetic suppression of Src regulates Rb activity and improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: While Src knockdown promoted aggregation of cells initially, the cells spread out more rapidly after differentiation compared with the PP1 treatment.
body_text.section: Genetic suppression of Src regulates Rb activity and improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: The suppression of the protein expression of Src was also reduced to a greater degree in PP1-treated cultures compared with genetic suppression of Src, potentially due to variations in potency and/ or technical limitations of using siRNA (Fig. 5, A and C).
body_text.section: Genetic suppression of Src regulates Rb activity and improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: Similar to Src knockdown, we next tested whether the PP1 treatment improves the differentiation potential of hPSCs across germ layers.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: We treated HUES6 hPSCs with 25 µM PP1 for 24 h and subsequently induced differentiation into each of the germ layers ( Fig. S4 A).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: The percentage of cells becoming Pax6+, Brachy+, and Sox17+ cells was quantified to assess multilineage differentiation potential into the ectodermal, mesodermal, and endodermal germ layers, respectively (Fig. S4 A).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: Treatment of hPSCs with 25 µM PP1 for 24 h before directed differentiation significantly increased the number and percentage of differentiated cells across all three germ layers (Fig.  S4, B and C).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: No significant differences in total cell number were observed for differentiations toward the ectodermal and endodermal germ layers.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: A 1-d differentiation toward the mesodermal germ layer resulted in a reduction in total cell number after the PP1 treatment.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: After PP1 treatment, the percentage of hPSCs that differentiated into each germ layer was enhanced by ∼10-fold for ectodermal differentiation, 60-fold for mesodermal differentiation, and 2.5-fold for endodermal differentiation (Fig. S4 C).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: At the time points assessed, differentiation rates of 40-75% were observed across all the germ layers after the PP1 treatment, roughly comparable to the differentiation rates observed for genetic suppression of Src (Fig. 5).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: Differences in these rates between the PP1 treatment and genetic suppression of Src could be due to variations in the potency of the treatments.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: To further evaluate how well stem cells differentiate into the three germ layers after the PP1 treatment, we used the highly quantitative PCR (qPCR)-based Scorecard assay as an assessment of lineage specification (Bock et al., 2011).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: Three published directed differentiation protocols were used to differentiate hPSCs into representative populations of the ectodermal (dEC), mesodermal (dME), and endodermal (dEN) germ layers (Gifford et al., 2013; Fig. 6 A).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: The expression levels of a panel of genes specific to pluripotent stem cells and the three germ layers were measured in control and PP1-treated hPSCs and differentiated cultures.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: For most germ layer markers, higher expression levels were observed in PP1-treated differentiated cells compared with controls ( Fig. 6 B).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: The mean expression across all ectodermal, mesodermal, and endodermal markers on the panel was also significantly higher in PP1-treated differentiated cells relative to controls (Fig. 6 B, right bars).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: These differences were generally not present in PP1-treated and control hPSCs before directed differentiation (Fig. S4 D).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: In comparison to a reference set of 14 other pluripotent stem cell lines, the PP1treated differentiated cells had a higher germ layer differentiation potential than control samples (Fig. S4, E and F) and often had higher potential than other cell lines in the reference set.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: These results show that the PP1 treatment improves lineage specification after directed differentiation by enhancing the expression of genes relevant for a given lineage.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: Together, these analyses show that the PP1 treatment improves the capacity for differentiation using six different induction protocols.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: Improvements in lineage specification would predict that the PP1 effects should persist to improve differentiation at subsequent stages of differentiation.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: To evaluate the long-term effects of PP1, hPSCs were differentiated through a 15-d directed differentiation protocol into Pdx1+ pancreatic progenitor cells after the initial 24-h 25 µM PP1 treatment (Fig. 6 C).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: The PP1 treatment of hPSCs increased the number of Pdx1+ cells by threefold, inducing a 70% differentiation rate (Fig. 6, D and E).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: The PP1-treated cells also continued to expand throughout the stages of the directed differentiation protocol (Fig. 6 F).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: Further differentiation of the PP1-treated hPSCs toward terminally differentiated cells of the pancreatic lineage (Fig. S5 A) promoted differentiation into Nkx6.1+ and Ngn3+ endocrine cells as well as hormone-expressing C-peptide+ cells (Fig. S5 B).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: Thus, the increased differentiation efficiency after PP1 treatment is sustained throughout subsequent stages of differentiation and shows that the PP1 treatment is capable of driving hPSCs past the initial germ layers toward later stages of development.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: In prior work, we showed that pretreatment with DMSO at a concentration of 1-2% could significantly improve the differentiation propensities of hPSCs (Chetty et al., 2013).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: We tested whether combining PP1 and DMSO could have beneficial effects on hPSC differentiation.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: While combining the two treatments (25 µM PP1 with 2% DMSO) simultaneously compromised cell survival (unpublished data), sequential treatment with a lower concentration of DMSO (0.5%) had positive effects.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: After a 24-h treatment with 25 µM PP1, hPSCs were treated with 0.5% DMSO for 24 h and then cultured in differentiation media with Wnt3a and Activin A for 24 h (Fig. S5 C).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: This com- bined treatment increased the percentage and absolute number of Brachy+ cells relative to cultures treated with PP1 alone in the HUES 6 line ( Fig. 1 and Fig. S5, D-F).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: The combined treat-ment increased the absolute yield of differentiated cells in other cell lines as well (Fig. S5 G).
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: These findings indicate that optimizing the concentrations and timing of the DMSO and PP1 Figure 6.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: PP1 treatment improves the specificity of differentiation of hPSCs.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: (A) Schematic of directed differentiation of HUES6 hPSCs into ectoderm (dEC, blue), mesoderm (dME, green), and endoderm (dEN, yellow) populations.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: (B) Difference in mean expression between PP1-treated and control samples, −∂CT = −(CT PP1 − CT C ONTROL ), for selected ectoderm (left), mesoderm (center), and endoderm (right) marker genes after directed differentiation into the three germ layers.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: All markers with −∂CT ≥ 1.9 or ≤ −1.9 are displayed, where −∂CT = 2 represents a fourfold increase in expression for PP1-treated versus control samples.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: The mean difference in expression for all ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm markers on the Scorecard panel (Life Technologies) is displayed as the rightmost bar.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: treatments could provide further benefits for directed differentiation.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: Using different doses of these two treatments at various stages of directed differentiation could also improve long-term differentiation potential and should be further explored.
body_text.section: PP1 treatment improves the differentiation capacity of hPSCs across all germ layers

body_text.text: In summary, the results show that a potent Src inhibitor, PP1, regulates the cell cycle and differentiation capacity of both human embryonic and iPSCs.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: A 24-h treatment with PP1 modulates the expression of genes involved in the G1 to S phase transition, enhances Rb activity, and increases the percent of cells in the early G1 phase of the cell cycle.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: After these effects, hPSCs respond more efficiently and effectively to various directed differentiation protocols, leading to improvements in differentiation potentials across all germ layers.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Genetic suppression of Src in hPSCs similarly activates Rb and improves differentiation capacity, suggesting an important role for Src in controlling proliferation and differentiation.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: These early manipulations of the starting state of hPSCs increase the output and specificity of differentiated cells at subsequent stages.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: The PP1 treatment enhances the yield of differentiated cells to 80% even in cell lines that would otherwise have low differentiation propensities.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: In cases where efficiencies are already high under control conditions, PP1 has no adverse effects.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Thus, the effects are durable in that they extend beyond the initial germ layer specification.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Our findings on the importance of the cell cycle mirror results in the literature on embryogenesis.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: In early development as well as in pluripotent stem cells, a truncated cell cycle initially supports the amplification of cells (Smith, 2001;Orford and Scadden, 2008).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: However, the cell cycle then lengthens as development progresses to incorporate gap phases and give cells the opportunity to become more specialized (Trelstad et al., 1967;Hartwell and Weinert, 1989;Murray and Kirschner, 1989;Frederick and Andrews, 1994;Edgar and Lehner, 1996).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Similarly, lengthening the truncated cell cycle of pluripotent stem cells through suppression of Src or small molecules such as PP1 may help direct their differentiation into specialized cell types.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Few factors have been identified to date that effectively regulate the pluripotent cell cycle and directed differentiation (Smith, 2001;Orford and Scadden, 2008;Zhu et al., 2009;Chetty et al., 2013;Li and Kirschner, 2014).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: PP1 has proven to be a potent tool to regulate the pluripotent G1 phase, as it enhances the hypophosphorylated state of Rb and enriches cells in the early G1 phase before directed differentiation.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Our findings also support recent work suggesting that the G1 phase of the cell cycle may play an important role in enhancing the differentiation of hPSCs (Sela et al., 2012;Pauklin and Vallier, 2013;Singh et al., 2013).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Given its role in regulating Rb and the cell cycle, PP1 could also be a useful tool in controlling the tumorigenicity of pluripotent stem cells and their differentiated progeny to enhance their therapeutic utility (Ben-David and Benvenisty, 2011).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: The robust impacts of the PP1 treatment and genetic suppression of Src on hPSCs are consistent with prior work showing the importance of Src tyrosine kinase activity in regulating cell proliferation in early development (Trelstad et al., 1967;Frederick and Andrews, 1994).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: In addition, with the evolution of multicellular organisms, a negative regulation of Src was acquired that proved to be critical for interactions and communications between cells (Segawa et al., 2006).
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Src inhibition may similarly play an important regulatory role as a single cell undergoes cell division into a multicellular organism in early development.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: More broadly, this study shows that the PP1 treatment alters the "starting state" of hPSCs to be more amenable to directed differentiation.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Manipulating this starting state, whether through PP1, direct inhibition of Src, or other tools, increases the utility of pluripotent stem cells.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: Studying how this state relates to the recently established primitive "reset" state of hPSCs (Takashima et al., 2014) could provide further mechanistic insights into how various pluripotent states control cell fate decisions and the developmental potential of pluripotent stem cells.
body_text.section: Discussion

body_text.text: All hPSC cultures were maintained at 37°C, 5% CO 2 and grown on a monolayer of irradiated CF1 mouse embryonic fibroblasts (MEFs; Glo-balStem) in hPSC medium consisting of KO-DMEM (Invitrogen), 10% KOSR (Invitrogen), 1% GlutaMAX, nonessential amino acids, penicillin/streptomycin, and 0.1% β-mercaptoethanol supplemented with 10 ng/ml bFGF (Invitrogen).
body_text.section: Materials and methods hPSC maintenance conditions

body_text.text: Medium was changed every 24 h, and lines were passaged using TrypLE (Invitrogen).
body_text.section: Materials and methods hPSC maintenance conditions

body_text.text: Before differentiation experiments, cells were expanded for at least two passages on Matrigel (BD) in mTeSR (STE MCELL Technologies) with 10 µM of ROCK inhibitor Y-27632 (Abcam).
body_text.section: Materials and methods hPSC maintenance conditions

body_text.text: The HUES cell lines (HUES6, HUES8, HUES49, and H9; Cowan et al., 2004;Osafune et al., 2008) and the iPSC line (iPSC11b; Boulting et al., 2011) were used in this study.
body_text.section: Materials and methods hPSC maintenance conditions

body_text.text: siRNA transfection.
body_text.section: Materials and methods hPSC maintenance conditions

body_text.text: Src siRNA (s13414, Life Technologies; Chr. 20: 35973088-36033821) and nontargeting control siRNA (4390843; Life Technologies) were transfected into hPSCs plated onto Matrigel-coated plates at 70% confluence.
body_text.section: Materials and methods hPSC maintenance conditions

body_text.text: Cells were transfected with either control siRNA (50 pmol) or Src siRNA (50 pmol) using Lipofectamine RNAimax transfection reagent (Invitrogen), according to the manufacturer's instructions.
body_text.section: Materials and methods hPSC maintenance conditions

body_text.text: Cells were subsequently either differentiated or collected for analysis 24 h after transfection.
body_text.section: Materials and methods hPSC maintenance conditions

body_text.text: For all differentiation studies, hPSCs were plated onto wells coated with growth factor-reduced Matrigel (BD) in mTeSR with 10 µM ROCK inhibitor Y-27632.
body_text.section: Differentiation protocols

body_text.text: Cells were plated at a density of 1-2 million per well of a six-well plate or 100,000-200,000 per well of a 96-well plate.
body_text.section: Differentiation protocols

body_text.text: 24 h before the onset of differentiation, cells were cultured in mTeSR with inhibitor treatment.
body_text.section: Differentiation protocols

body_text.text: Inhibitor medium was removed after 24 h and replaced with differentiation-inducing media at the start of each differentiation, with replacement of medium every day in all protocols.
body_text.section: Differentiation protocols

body_text.text: Treatments in this study include PP1 (Thermo Fisher Scientific), PP2 (Tocris Bioscience), 1-Naphthyl PP1 (Tocris Bioscience), Saracatinib (Thermo Fisher Scientific), Bosutinib (Sigma-Aldrich), K252a (Sigma-Aldrich), N-[(2R)-2,3-Dihydroxypropoxy]-3,4-difluoro-2-[(2-fluoro-4-iodophenyl)amino]-benzamide (Stemgent), Roscovitine (Sigma-Aldrich), CDK2 inhibitor (EMD Millipore), and Palbociclib HCl (Selleck Chemicals) at dosages of 1 µM, 5 µM, 10 µM, 25 µM, 40 µM, and 50 µM for 24 h.
body_text.section: Differentiation protocols

body_text.text: To induce differentiation into the ectodermal, mesodermal, and endodermal germ layers and pancreatic endocrine lineage, cells were directly differentiated as follows.
body_text.section: Differentiation protocols

body_text.text: Ectoderm.
body_text.section: Differentiation protocols

body_text.text: Cells were cultured in KO-DMEM (Invitrogen) medium containing 10% knockout serum replacement (Invitrogen) and supplemented with Noggin (500 ng/ml; R&D Systems) and 4-[4-(1,3-benzodioxol-5-yl)-5-(2-pyridinyl)-1H-imidazol-2-yl]benzamide (10 µM; Tocris) for 3-4 d.
body_text.section: Differentiation protocols

body_text.text: Mesoderm.
body_text.section: Differentiation protocols

body_text.text: Cells were cultured in Advanced RPMI 1640 (reduced serum; Invitrogen) or RPMI 1640 medium (Invitrogen) supplemented with human recombinant AA (100 ng/ml) + Wnt3a (20 ng/ml; R&D Systems) for 1 d.
body_text.section: Differentiation protocols

body_text.text: Endoderm.
body_text.section: Differentiation protocols

body_text.text: Cells were cultured in MCDB-131 medium (Invitrogen) supplemented with NaHCO 3 (2.5 g/liter), 1% GlutaMAX, glucose (5.5 mM), 0.1% FAF-BSA (Proliant/Lampire), and ITS:X (1:50,000; Invitrogen), and treated with Wnt3a (20 ng/ml) + AA (100 ng/ml) for 1 d and then AA (100 ng/ml) for 3 d.
body_text.section: Differentiation protocols

body_text.text: Pancreatic endocrine differentiation.
body_text.section: Differentiation protocols

body_text.text: Cells were cultured in MCDB-131 medium supplemented with NaHCO 3 (2.5 g/liter), 1% GlutaMAX, glucose (5.5 mM), 0.1% FAF-BSA, and ITS:X (1:50,000), and were treated with Wnt3a (20 ng/ml) + AA (100 ng/ml) for 1 d, AA (100 ng/ml) for 3 d, and FGF7 (50 ng/ml; PeproTech) for 2 d.
body_text.section: Differentiation protocols

body_text.text: For further endocrine differentiation, cells were cultured in MCDB-131 medium supplemented with NaHCO 3 (2.5 g/liter), 1% GlutaMAX, glucose (8 mM), 2% FAF-BSA, and ITS:X (1:200), and treated for 4 d with FGF7 (50 ng/ml) + noggin (100 ng/ml) + retinoic acid (2 µM; Sigma-Aldrich) + SANT-1 (0.25 µM; Sigma-Aldrich) + AA (20 ng/ ml); for 3 d with SANT-1 (0.25 µM) + PdBu (200 nM; EMD) + noggin (100 ng/ml); and for 4-6 d with noggin (100 ng/ml) + Alk5 inhibitor (1 µM; Axxora).
body_text.section: Differentiation protocols

body_text.text: Directed differentiations for the scorecard analyses were performed using the following previously published protocols (Gifford et al., 2013).
body_text.section: Differentiation protocols

body_text.text: Ectoderm.
body_text.section: Differentiation protocols

body_text.text: Ectoderm differentiation was induced using A83-01 (2 µm; Tocris Bioscience), PNU 74654 (2 µm; Tocris Bioscience), Dorsomorphin (2 µm; Tocris Bioscience), and DMEM/F12 (Life Technologies) containing 15% knockout serum replacement (Life Technologies) for 4 d.
body_text.section: Differentiation protocols

body_text.text: Mesoderm.
body_text.section: Differentiation protocols

body_text.text: Mesoderm differentiation was induced in DMEM/ F12 (Life Technologies) and 0.5% FBS (HyClone; GE Healthcare), with Activin A (100 ng/ml; R&D Systems) for 1 d, and subsequently induced with BMP4 (100 ng/ml; R&D Systems), VEGF (100 ng/ml; R&D Systems), and FGF2 (20 ng/ml; Millipore) for 3 d.
body_text.section: Differentiation protocols

body_text.text: Endoderm.
body_text.section: Differentiation protocols

body_text.text: Endoderm differentiation was induced in Advanced RPMI (Invitrogen) and 0.5% FBS (HyClone), with Activin A (100 ng/ ml; R&D Systems) and LiCl (2 µg/ml; R&D Systems) for 4 d.
body_text.section: Differentiation protocols

body_text.text: Cells were rinsed in PBS and fixed in 4% PFA (Sigma-Aldrich) for 30 min.
body_text.section: Immunocytochemistry and quantification

body_text.text: After the rinses, cells were blocked for 1 h at room temperature in 5% donkey serum (Jackson ImmunoResearch Laboratories, Inc.) and 0.3% Triton X-100 in PBS.
body_text.section: Immunocytochemistry and quantification

body_text.text: All primary antibody incubations were done overnight at 4°C in blocking solution at a 1:500 dilution unless otherwise noted.
body_text.section: Immunocytochemistry and quantification

body_text.text: Primary antibodies used in this study were: Oct4 (mouse; R&D Systems), Sox1 (goat; R&D Systems), Pax6 (rabbit; Covance), Brachyury (goat; R&D Systems), Sox17 (goat; R&D Systems), Pdx1 (goat; R&D Systems), Nkx6.1 (mouse; University of Iowa, Developmental Hybridoma Bank), Ngn3 (sheep; R&D Systems), C-peptide (rat; Developmental Studies Hybridoma Bank), pRb 780 (1:350; Rb phosphorylation at Ser780; rabbit; Cell Signaling Technology), and underphosphorylated Rb (1:100; mouse; BD).
body_text.section: Immunocytochemistry and quantification

body_text.text: Cells were rinsed the next day, followed by secondary antibody incubation for 1 h at room temperature at a 1:500 dilution.
body_text.section: Immunocytochemistry and quantification

body_text.text: Secondary antibodies (Invitrogen) conjugated to Alexa Fluor 488 or 594 were used to visualize primary antibodies.
body_text.section: Immunocytochemistry and quantification

body_text.text: After PBS rinses, all nuclei were visualized by staining with Hoechst 33342 (1:1,000; Invitrogen).
body_text.section: Immunocytochemistry and quantification

body_text.text: Image acquisition and quantification.
body_text.section: Immunocytochemistry and quantification

body_text.text: Immunofluorescent images were taken using a microscope (Observer.D1; Carl Zeiss) using an LD A-Plan 10×/0.25 NA Ph1 M27 objective lens with the DAPI, GFP, or Texas red fluorochromes.
body_text.section: Immunocytochemistry and quantification

body_text.text: Cells were imaged in PBS at room temperature, and images were acquired using the microscopy camera Axiom 503 mono(D) with the acquisition software AxioVision Rel 4.7 (Carl Zeiss).
body_text.section: Immunocytochemistry and quantification

body_text.text: For quantification analyses, 30 10× fields per well were acquired and quantified using a high-content screening system (ArrayScan VTI; Cellomics Technology).
body_text.section: Immunocytochemistry and quantification

body_text.text: Cells labeled by antibody staining and total cell number (based on DAPI nuclei staining) were quantified to obtain percentages of target cell types.
body_text.section: Immunocytochemistry and quantification

body_text.text: For intracellular antibody staining, cells were fixed in 4% PFA for 20 min at 4°C followed by two PBS washes.
body_text.section: Flow cytometry

body_text.text: Cells were resuspended in blocking solution consisting of 5% donkey serum and 0.3% Triton X-100 in PBS.
body_text.section: Flow cytometry

body_text.text: Cells were then incubated for 30 min at 4°C with primary antibody RbAP46/48 (1:500; rabbit; Active Motif North America) or Ki67 (1:500; rabbit; Abcam) and washed twice in PBS.
body_text.section: Flow cytometry

body_text.text: Last, cells were incubated with secondary antibody donkey anti-rabbit Alexa Fluor 594 (1:500; Invitrogen) for 30 min at 4°C and washed twice before assessment on a flow cytometer (LSR II FACS; BD) and analysis using the FlowJo software.
body_text.section: Flow cytometry

body_text.text: Cells were harvested with TrypLE Express (Invitrogen), washed with cold PBS, and resuspended with annexin-binding buffer (50 mM Hepes, 700 mM NaCl, and 12.5 mM CaCl 2 , pH 7.4) to a final concentration of 10 6 cells/ml.
body_text.section: Annexin V-propidium iodide staining

body_text.text: 5 µl of Annexin V Alexa Fluor 488 conjugate (Molecular Probes) and 1 µl of 100 µg/ml propidium iodide (Molecular Probes) were added per 100 µl of cell suspension.
body_text.section: Annexin V-propidium iodide staining

body_text.text: After 15 min of incubation at room temperature, 400 µl of annexin-binding buffer was added per 100 µl of cell suspension.
body_text.section: Annexin V-propidium iodide staining

body_text.text: Samples were mixed gently and left on ice until analysis.
body_text.section: Annexin V-propidium iodide staining

body_text.text: Cells were assessed with a flow cytometer (LSR II FACS; BD) and analyzed using FlowJo software.
body_text.section: Annexin V-propidium iodide staining

body_text.text: Cells were lysed using the RIPA lysis buffer (Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc.).
body_text.section: Western blot analysis

body_text.text: Proteins were separated by 7.5% SDS-PAGE (Bio-Rad Laboratories) and transferred to nitrocellulose membranes (Bio-Rad Laboratories).
body_text.section: Western blot analysis

body_text.text: The membranes were blocked in 3% BSA in 0.1% Tween 20 TBS for 1 h at room temperature and then incubated with the following primary antibodies overnight at 4°C: Src (47405; 1:1,000; rabbit; Abcam), Src (16885; 1:1,000; mouse; Abcam), ppRb (G3-245; 1:1,000; mouse; BD), underphosphorylated Rb (G99-549; 1:1,000; mouse; BD), or GAP DH (MAB374; 1:1,000; mouse; Millipore) as the loading control.
body_text.section: Western blot analysis

body_text.text: After washing, the membranes were incubated with secondary antibodies for 1 h at room temperature: anti-mouse HRP (1:3,000; Cell Signaling Technology) or anti-rabbit HRP (1:5,000; Cell Signaling Technology), and then incubated in chemiluminescent HRP substrate (Millipore) for signal detection and development.
body_text.section: Western blot analysis

body_text.text: Total RNAs were isolated from purified cells of untreated and PP1treated hPSCs using the RNeasy mini kit (QIA GEN) and reverse transcribed using Superscript III RT (Invitrogen), according to the manufacturer's instructions.
body_text.section: RNA isolation and gene expression analyses by real-time PCR

body_text.text: Real-time qPCR reactions were analyzed with a Mastercycler realplex 4 Sequence Detector (Eppendorf) via SYBR green (QuantitectTM SYBR Green PCR kit; QIA GEN).
body_text.section: RNA isolation and gene expression analyses by real-time PCR

body_text.text: The relative gene expression level of each sample was expressed as a relative quantitation (RQ) value determined by the 2 − ddCT method that represents the fold change in gene expression normalized to the housekeeping gene, GAP DH.
body_text.section: RNA isolation and gene expression analyses by real-time PCR

body_text.text: The relative gene expression level of each sample was also compared with an internal control, i.e., untreated hPSCs.
body_text.section: RNA isolation and gene expression analyses by real-time PCR

body_text.text: Complementary DNA PCR primer sequences are shown in Table S1.
body_text.section: RNA isolation and gene expression analyses by real-time PCR

body_text.text: Total RNA was extracted from frozen cell pellets using Ambion Pure Link RNA Mini kit (Life Technologies).
body_text.section: qPCR and Scorecard analysis

body_text.text: Eight cDNA reactions were set up from 1 µg of total RNA per sample using a High-Capacity cDNA RT kit (Life Technologies).
body_text.section: qPCR and Scorecard analysis

body_text.text: qPCR was performed on 384-well TaqMan hPSC Scorecard plates using Viia7 RUO software and a ViiA7 instrument (Applied Biosystems).
body_text.section: qPCR and Scorecard analysis

body_text.text: Data were normalized to the mean expression level of five control genes that are highly invariant in expression during directed differentiation.
body_text.section: qPCR and Scorecard analysis

body_text.text: Differentiation potential was calculated (Bock et al., 2011) for four gene classes (EC, ectoderm; ME, mesoderm; EN, endoderm; PP, pluripotent).
body_text.section: qPCR and Scorecard analysis

body_text.text: Cells were trypsinized and fixed in 4% PFA for 20 min on ice and stained with Hoechst 33342 (5 µg/ml; Invitrogen) in PBS for 30 min.
body_text.section: Cell cycle analysis

body_text.text: Equal numbers of cells were assessed for each cell line on a flow cytometer (LSR II FACS; BD) and analyzed using FlowJo software.
body_text.section: Cell cycle analysis

body_text.text: For statistical comparisons, mean values of two or more independent experiments were subjected to unpaired two-tailed Student's t tests.
body_text.section: Statistical analysis

body_text.text: P-values ≤0.05 were considered significant.
body_text.section: Statistical analysis

body_text.text: Online supplemental material Fig. S1 shows cell viability after the PP1 treatment.
body_text.section: Statistical analysis

body_text.text: Fig. S2 shows how various cell cycle inhibitors regulate the differentiation potential of hPSCs.
body_text.section: Statistical analysis

body_text.text: Fig. S3 shows the cell cycle profiles of several cell lines after the PP1 treatment.
body_text.section: Statistical analysis

body_text.text: Fig. S4 shows how PP1 enhances the differentiation potential across all germ layers using various directed differentiation protocols.
body_text.section: Statistical analysis

body_text.text: Fig. S5 shows that the initial PP1 treatment has positive impacts on terminal differentiation and provides benefits on differentiation capacity when combined with a DMSO treatment.
body_text.section: Statistical analysis

body_text.text: Table S1 includes primer sequences used in the study.
body_text.section: Statistical analysis

body_text.section: Statistical analysis
